title: Understanding Menstrual Disorders
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value:
Menstrual disorders refer to any changes or problems with a person's menstrual cycle, including irregular timing, unusually heavy or light bleeding, severe pain, or the absence of periods.

These disorders are common and may be temporary or linked to underlying health conditions. Understanding them helps with early recognition and proper treatment.

content.description: Up to 80% of women experience some form of menstrual disorder during their lifetime.

content.title: What's Normal For You
content.description: What's "normal" is what's normal for you - sudden changes are worth checking with your healthcare provider.

items.title: PMS
items.description: Physical and emotional symptoms before your period

items.title: PMDD
items.description: Severe physical and emotional symptoms before your period

items.title: Common Symptoms
items: Periods fewer than 21 days apart or more than 3 months apart
Bloating or fullness in the abdomen
Headaches, low mood, or emotional distress

items.title: When to Seek Urgent Help
items: Bleeding so heavy you soak through pads/tampons every hour
Severe pain not eased by painkillers
Fainting, dizziness, or signs of severe anaemia

tags: Eating disorders or sudden weight changes

content.value: Treatment depends on the type and severity of your condition

items.title: Lifestyle Changes
items.content:
Simple changes that can help manage symptoms:
- Reduce salt, caffeine, sugar and alcohol before your period
- Stay active with regular exercise
- Manage stress through relaxation techniques
- Get enough rest and maintain good sleep hygiene

items.title: Medical Treatment
items.content:
Medical options your healthcare provider might recommend:
- Pain relievers for cramps and discomfort
- Hormonal contraceptives to regulate or reduce bleeding
- Hormone therapy to balance hormone levels
- Iron supplements if you have anaemia from heavy bleeding

items.title: Surgical Treatment
items.content:
For severe cases that don't respond to other treatments:
- Hysteroscopy or laparoscopy to treat specific areas of concern
- Endometrial ablation to destroy the womb lining and stop periods
- Hysterectomy (removal of the womb) - only if other treatments haven't worked and you don't plan more pregnancies

content.value: Simple steps to help manage and reduce the impact of menstrual disorders.

steps: Track menstrual cycles and symptoms regularly
Maintain a healthy weight and balanced diet
Reduce stress and practice relaxation techniques
Manage underlying conditions early (e.g., thyroid, PCOS)

content.title: Why It Matters
content.description: While not all menstrual disorders can be prevented, understanding your cycle helps detect changes early. Early management leads to better control, reduced discomfort, and quicker treatment when needed.

content.value: Menstrual disorders are common and often manageable with proper care.

items.text: Menstrual disorders vary widely from heavy bleeding to absent periods
Early identification of symptoms ensures more effective treatment
Tracking your cycle helps detect changes sooner
Seek medical help if your period suddenly becomes irregular or painful
Most menstrual disorders are manageable with proper care
